instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15‚Äù power adapter to a 13‚Äù Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15‚Äù macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC‚Äôs voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
Hi, I have here this board on my desk and it have strange DC readings. No power no green light, complete dead. No water damage.

Voltages:

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 15,00V this should be 18,5v?

<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> Pin 1 - 15,00v
<RESISTOR>R7006</RESISTOR> Pin 1 - it starts with 0,7v and goes after a while below 0,2v

<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> Pin 3 - 14,11v

L7130 - 0,176 on either side
L7095 - short on both sides.

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP>

Pin 1 - 0.58v
Pin 2 - 0.11v
Pin 3 - 1.18v
Pin 4 - 0.32v
Pin 6 - 14,11v
Pin 8 - 14,11v

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: I have checked with thermal camera the <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> is getting hot if plug in only the ac adapter. I have changed the <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> but still same issue.Any ideas? I', still wondering why the PPDCIN is 15,00v and not 18,5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"I', still wondering why the PPDCIN is 15,00v and not 18,5v"
Stop to make wrong assumptions!
Did you ever check with other charger?
That is the nominal charger voltage; depends by its specifications.

"L7095 - short on both sides."
Once <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> removed from the board, did you check if still short there?
If yes, no reason to change it.
I bet your short is not caused by <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>.
Removing L7095 helps to see where the short remains; instead of removing <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>.

Can you post the exact ohm value of that short?
Usually voltage injection method helps to find the culprit; in case of pure short, or very low ohm value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: Thank you for answer. I have just measured it looks like the short is gone when I unplug the I/O cable from the DC charger. If unplugged the numbers are on Pin 1 L7095 it is 83kohm and Pin 2 51kohm. If plugged in the readings are 0,7ohms and 1,2ohms on other side L7095. I have an other DC Board here but it is not from 2015 model it is from 2013 but it makes still the same short when I/O plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
You should look at connectors layout before making such substitution!!!

Inspect LIO flex connectors for corrosion.
Also inspect J9500 pins under microscope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: All connectors are fine, I have all cleaned no corrosion. All Pins also ok. The charger is also ok works great on macbook pro. I have noticed that I have accidently plugged in the LIO flex in the wrong way üòî turned 180¬∞. Now the short is gone even if plugged in but there are still 15,00v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
I said the input voltage depends by charger type; what is not clear?
If you connect 45-60-85W model, will get different voltage, don't you think?

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 80495, member: 682"]
If you connect 45-60-85W model, will get different voltage, don't you think?
[/QUOTE]
Now I understand what you mean üòä  my charger is 45W

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present now. Measured on L7095 Pin 2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,2v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3,3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0,00v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: The <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is produced from <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> but on the <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0,00v. How can it be that the same line on the one side of the board is present and on the other not present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
Ok I made a measurment fault. In OpenBoardview I had to tick the option "whole" because if search <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> it shows me all the other lines on the board with all prefixes even if I click on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, sorry my fault. So the <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is not present

Edit: The short to ground on <CAPACITOR>C8020</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 is about 374ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,2v"
Communication fault between SMC and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3,3v
------------------
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is not present"
Really no voltage at L7560?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: Just double checked there is no voltage on both pins on L7560

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3,3v"
When and where did you get this?
Is impostant to post correct information.
Check if there appears voltage in the first few seconds, or pulses at least.

<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still present?
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 80536, member: 682"]
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3,3v"
When and where did you get this?
[/QUOTE]
I got this on <CAPACITOR>C5126</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 but this is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0,00v on <CAPACITOR>C8130</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 so this line is not present

After plug in charger <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> raises slowly from 0,00volts to 14,7miliVolts in about 2 minutes, checked with oscilloscope

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,42v is present on <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR> Pin 1

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,2v is present on F7140 Pin 2

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 0,00v on <RESISTOR>R5198</RESISTOR> Pin 1

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 0,00v on <RESISTOR>R5185</RESISTOR> Pin 1

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0,013v on <TRANSISTOR>Q3000</TRANSISTOR> Pin 3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
What about <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?
If present, check for 12MHz at Y5110.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 80545, member: 682"]
What about <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
[/QUOTE]
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 0,468v on <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> Pin 1

Is this enough for present or too low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
Remove <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and check it again.
If still low, be sure <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> is good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5110</CHIP> removed still 0,469v on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

Checked <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> = 100kohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: Removed <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> now <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 0,039v on <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> Pin 1

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: Clean/remove J6100...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message:
omg i cannot believe, I cleaned up the connector J6100 and now we have this voltages:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,2v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3,3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3,3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,42v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,42v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,42v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3,3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3,38v

I reassembled the macbook and voila this thing works!! Thank you so much you're awesome :cool:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: I hope you've put back <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power no green light strange DC readings
threads.message: Yes. After cleaning the J6100 I connected the AC Adapter and the light was amber on the Magsafe. After that I put back the other parts checked the voltages and reassembled the macbook. Thank you again!
